questions.text: In which of the following parts of the bone are hairpin bends of end arteries abundantly present?
questions.solution:
Hairpin bends of end arteries are seen abundantly in the metaphysis.

The metaphysis is the portion of a long bone between the epiphysis and diaphysis. It is the zone of active growth and is highly vascular. Before epiphysial fusion, the metaphysis is richly supplied through end arteries that form 'hairpin' bends.

The metaphysis is the most common location for osteomyelitis in children because the bacteria or emboli are easily trapped in the hairpin bends, thereby causing infarction.

questions.text: A person develops headache and breathlessness on a trekking expedition following rapid ascent to over 3000 metres above the sea level. Which of the following is not used in the treatment of this condition?
questions.solution:
The symptoms of headache and breathlessness following rapid ascent indicate acute mountain/altitude sickness and IV digoxin is not used to treat this condition. 

On ascent to high altitudes, the low partial pressure of oxygen leads to hypoxia and systemic arteriolar dilatation. Consequently, the capillary pressure rises with increased transudation of fluid into the brain tissue and the following symptoms are seen:

  • Headache
  • Irritation
  • Insomnia
  • Breathlessness
  • Nausea and vomiting

Treatment involves administration of oxygen, descent to a lower altitude and administration of acetazolamide. Acetazolamide counteracts hypoxia by stimulating respiration and also reduces the formation of cerebrospinal fluid, thereby reducing intracranial tension.

Portable hyperbaric chambers are increasingly being used in the treatment of high-altitude illnesses when rapid descent is not possible. These chambers are available in armed forces hospitals in high-altitude areas.

questions.text: A 6-month-old boy was admitted with failure to thrive. Laboratory tests showed hypoglycemia and high glutamine and uracil levels in urine. Gastric tube feeding was not tolerated. The child became comatose and then parenteral dextrose was given. The child recovered from coma within 24 hours. What is the likely enzyme defect?
questions.solution:
From the given clinical scenario, the diagnosis is hyperammonemia type 2, which is due to the deficiency of the enzyme ornithine transcarbamoylase.

There is an accumulation of carbamoyl phosphate, which then enters into pyrimidine synthesis producing orotic acid and uracil and leading to orotic aciduria and high uracil in blood and urine.

High glutamine: Since the ammonia from glutamine is not converted into urea, its level increases. Glutamate is not regenerated.

Hypoglycemia: Since glutamate is not available for transamination, amino acids cannot be used for gluconeogenesis. Hence, the glucose level drops in blood.

Treatment:

Limiting intake of ammonia and increasing its excretion. Dietary protein, a metabolic source of ammonium, is restricted and caloric intake is provided by glucose and fat.

Addition of Phenylbutyrate which scavenges nitrogen.

Related Pearl: Urea Cycle and its disorders

questions.text: A 27-year-old woman presents with urinary frequency, urgency, and burning during urination of two days duration. She has also noticed a scant vaginal discharge. Which of the following additional findings would be most suggestive of pyelonephritis in this patient?
questions.solution:
In the given case scenario, WBC casts are most suggestive of pyelonephritis. 

The urine contains many leukocytes (pyuria) derived from the inflammatory infiltrate, but pyuria does not differentiate upper from lower urinary tract infection. The finding of leukocyte casts, typically rich in neutrophils (pus casts), indicates renal involvement because casts are formed only in tubules.

Note:Ascending infection is the most common cause of clinical pyelonephritis.

Note: Sterile pyuria is defined as white cells in the urine in the absence of significant bacterial growth.

questions.text: A child, upon ingestion of shellfish, developed a tingling sensation in the mouth, swelling of the face, lips, and tongue, and also complained of abdominal pain and dizziness. What type of reaction is this?
questions.solution:
This is an example of an anaphylactic reaction after ingestion of an allergen(shellfish). It is an IgE mediated type of hypersensitivity reaction. 

The primary mediators are histamine and serotonin. The secondary mediators are prostaglandins and leukotrienes. The clinical manifestations may be local or systemic and range from mild rhinitis to fatal anaphylaxis.

questions.text: You are counseling a patient with gastroesophageal reflux disease about the need for long-term therapy with proton-pump inhibitors. All of the following are complications of this therapy, except:
questions.solution:
Long-term PPI therapy is not associated with hypogastrinemia but is associated with hypergastrinemia. This hypergastrinemia contributes to rebound gastric acid hypersecretion if PPI therapy is discontinued.

Chronic PPI therapy is associated with: 

  • Decreased vitamin B12 absorption
  • Increased susceptibility to infections- hospital-acquired pneumonia, pseudomembranous enterocolitis
  • Reduced calcium absorption increases the risk of fractures

questions.text: A 5-year-old child with a ​history of perianal pain is brought to the OPD. On subjecting the specimen from the perianal region to a test, it produces yellow rhombic crystals of spermine picrate. What is the test done?
questions.solution:
The test done in the scenario is Barberio test. It is used to detect seminal fluid.

When saturated aqueous or alcoholic solution of picric acid is added to the spermatic fluid, yellow needle-shaped rhombic crystals of spermine picrate are produced.

Other options: 

Option B: Florence test: 

  • The suspected seminal stain is extracted with 10% hydrochloric acid and a drop of it is placed over a slide.
  • A coverslip is placed over it and a drop of Florence solution (potassium iodide, iodine, and water) is made to run under the coverslip.
  • If semen is present, dark brown rhombic or needle-shaped crystals of choline iodide appear immediately.

Option C: Takayama test (Haemochromogen crystal test): 

  • The test is used to detect suspected bloodstains. Small piece of suspected material is added on a glass slide.
  • Then, 2-3 drops of Takayama reagent is added and covered with a coverslip.
  • If it is a bloodstain, pink feathery crystals of haemochromogen or reduced alkaline haematin appear in a few minutes.

Option D: Teichmann test (Haemin Crystal Test): 

  • The test is used to detect suspected bloodstains.
  • Small piece of suspected material is placed on a glass slide. Then, 2-3 drops of glacial acetic acid and a small crystal of sodium chloride are added to the glass slide and covered with a coverslip. The slide is then heated.
  • If bloodstain is present, faint yellowish-red to brownish-black rhombic crystals of haemin or haematin chloride appear.
  • When hydrogen peroxide is added, the haematin crystals give bubbles of gas.

questions.text: 65 year old male presents with painless cervical lymphadenopathy and right sided deafness. On examination, dull tympanic membrane on right side and tympanometry shows curve B. Most probable diagnosis is
questions.solution:
• Painless cervical lymphadenopathy is the most common presenting feature of nasopharyngeal carcinoma.
  • Presence of unilateral serous otitis media in an adult should raise suspicion of nasopharyngeal growth. (Eustachian tube obstruction leads to serous otitis media which causes deafness)

  • Painless cervical lymphadenopathy is the most common (60-90%) presenting feature of nasopharyngeal carcinoma followed by- 

    • Hearing loss
    • Nasal obstruction
    • Epistaxis
    • Cranial nerve palsies -Cranial nerves V and VI are the most commonly involved among all the cranial nerves. 
    • Headache
    • Earache
    • Neck pain
    • Weight loss
  • Dull tympanic membrane and type B curve on tympanometry are features of serous otitis media.

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman is being counseled for surgery for her long-standing dacryocystitis. Which of the following is the surgery of choice?
questions.solution:
The treatment of choice for chronic dacryocystitis is dacryocystorhinostomy (DCR) as it re-establishes the lacrimal drainage.

One of the sequelae of chronic dacryocystitis is mucocele formation, which when infected, leads to pyocele formation and finally lacrimal fibrosis. Treatment of lacrimal sac fibrosis is dacryocystectomy.

questions.text: A 15 years old girl has received complete immunization against tetanus 7 years ago. Now she presents with a contaminated wound sustained 6 hours ago. She should now be given?

choices.text: Human tetanus immunoglobulin and single dose of toxoid

questions.solution:
The girl should be given a single dose of tetanus toxoid alone

She presented with a contaminated wound sustained 6 hours ago and she has received complete immunization against tetanus 7 years back, which comes under Category B of Tetanus Immunization.

questions.text: A patient's fasting plasma glucose is 122 mg/dl and post prandial plasma glucose is 138 mg/dl. Which of the following criteria does he fall under according to the WHO diagnostic criteria for diabetes and intermediate hyperglycemia?
questions.solution:
The patient's values fall under the criteria for impaired fasting glucose.

WHO Diagnostic criteria for diabetes and intermediate hyperglycemia: (It is important for both the fasting plasma glucose and the post prandial plasma glucose to match to make a diagnosis).

Fasting plasma glucose Post prandial plasma glucose Diagnosis
≥ 126 mg/dl > 200 mg/dl Diabetes
< 126 mg/dl 140-200 mg/dl Impaired glucose tolerance
110-125 mg/dl < 140 mg/dl Impaired fasting glucose

questions.text: A 24-year-old pregnant woman has completed her 1st antenatal visit under the maternal and child health program (MCH). Now she is 14 weeks pregnant. How many more antenatal visits does she need to complete to fulfill the minimum requirement for antenatal visits under the MCH?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, the lady should complete 3 more visits to fulfill the minimum requirement of antenatal visits under MCH.

The minimum number of antenatal visits according to MCH is 4.

  • 1st visit – within 12 weeks, preferably as soon as the pregnancy is suspected.
  • 2nd visit – between 14 and 26 weeks
  • 3rd visit – between 28 and 34 weeks
  • 4th visit – between 36 weeks and term

It is advised that the woman should visit the medical officer at the PHC for an antenatal check-up during 3rd visit.

The minimum number of antenatal visits according to the WHO (not MCH), is 8.

The ideal number of antenatal visits a mother should take to the antenatal clinic is:

  • Once a month during the first 7 months
  • Twice a month during the next month
  • Once a week, thereafter if everything is normal.

questions.text: Mr. Ramesh presented with a 3-week history of crampy abdominal pain associated with diarrhoea. Which of the following features supports a diagnosis of irritable bowel syndrome?

choices.text: Persistent diarrhoea after a 48 hour fast
Onset of symptoms during a period of stress

questions.solution:
The onset of symptoms during a period of stress or emotional upset is a feature that supports a diagnosis of irritable bowel syndrome (IBS).

Features in favour of IBS:

  • Abdominal pain that improves/worsens with defecation
  • Association with stress or emotional symptoms
  • Small volume of stools

Features not in favour of IBS:

  • Onset of symptoms in old age
  • Presence of fever and weight loss
  • Persistent diarrhoea after a 48h fast
  • Nocturnal diarrhoea
  • Steatorrhoea

questions.text: A 70-year-old chronic smoker is being evaluated for chronic diarrhea, steatorrhea, and weight loss. On examination, pallor was noted. Peripheral smear revealed macrocytes and hypersegmented neutrophils. Stool examination showed elevated calprotectin and a positive guaiac test. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above scenario is suggestive of Crohn's disease presenting as jejunoileitis. This is evidenced by the presence of features of malabsorption such as steatorrhea, chronic diarrhea, and vitamin B12 deficiency anemia.

The fecal calprotectin and lactoferrin are elevated in inflammatory conditions like inflammatory bowel disease, but not in irritable bowel syndrome. 

The stool guaiac test or guaiac fecal occult blood test (gFOBT) reveals the presence of microscopic levels of blood suggesting Crohn's disease. Gross bleeding per rectum is more characteristic of ulcerative colitis.  

Additionally, smoking is a risk factor for Crohn's disease. However, it is a protective factor in ulcerative colitis.

questions.text: A middle-aged obese female patient has recently been diagnosed with type 2 DM. The best initial drug of choice for the clinical management of type 2 diabetes mellitus in obese patients is ______
questions.solution:
Metformin is the best initial drug of choice for the clinical management of diabetes mellitus in an obese patient.

Metformin

  • Drug of choice in obese Type 2 diabetes mellitus patients
  • Mechanism of Action: Reduced hepatic glucose production
  • Advantages :
    • Modest weight loss
    • No hypoglycemia
    • No plasma level monitoring
  • Disadvantages :
    • Nausea, Diarrhea
    • Lactic acidosis
    • Vitamin B12 deficiency
  • Contraindications :
    • Liver failure
    • Chronic renal failure
    • Chronic hepatic failure
    • Alcoholics

questions.text: Which of the following people would you not classify as a high risk contact of SARS-CoV2?

choices.text: A family member who lives in the same household as the patient
A doctor who examined the patient with a surgical mask and gloves
A passenger in the same bus as a symptomatic patient for 6 hours and the patient later tested positive
A sanitary worker who cleaned the linens of the patient

questions.solution:
A person traveling in the same environment and not having significant exposure to the confirmed case is not classified as a high-risk contact.

A contact of COVID-19 is a person living in the same household or having direct physical contact with the patient/infectious secretions without appropriate PPE or a person who was in a closed environment or at a distance of within 1 meter of a COVID-19 case.

High-risk contacts:

  • Touched body fluids of the patient
  • Had direct contact with the body of the patient during the physical examination without proper PPE
  • Touched or cleaned the linens, clothes, or dishes of the patient
  • Lives in the same household as the patient
  • Comes in close contact (within 1 meter) with the patient without necessary precautions
  • A passenger in close proximity with the symptomatic patient for 6 hours and the patient later tested positive

Low-risk contacts:

  • Shared the same space but does not have a high-risk exposure to the confirmed case.
  • Travelled in the same environment but does not have a high-risk exposure to the confirmed case.

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman presented to the OPD with a 4 x 2 cm painless lump in the left breast. She is planned for a mastectomy. Sentinel lymph node biopsy done showed involvement of level 1 lymph nodes. Which of the following lymph nodes will not be affected in her case?
questions.solution:
Interpectoral lymph nodes are level 2 axillary lymph nodes. Level 1 axillary lymph nodes include anterior, lateral, and posterior/subscapular nodes.

Related Pearl: Lymphatic drainage of breast

The lymphatics of the breast drain predominantly into

  • The axillary lymph nodes (85%)
  • Internal mammary lymph nodes
  • Posterior intercostal/Interpectoral/ Rotter’s lymph nodes

The axillary nodes are arranged in the following groups:

Level I (Lymph nodes located lateral to pectoralis minor muscle):

  • Lateral, along the axillary vein - drains most of upper limb
  • Anterior (external mammary group or pectoral group), along the lateral thoracic vessels - drains most of breast.(1st relay station for lymph)
  • Posterior (scapular group), along the subscapular vessels

Level II (Lymph nodes located superficial or deep to pectoralis minor muscle):

  • Central, embedded in fat in the centre of the axilla- receive drainage from Level I groups

Level III (Lymph nodes located medial to pectoralis minor muscle):

  • Apical (sub-clavicular group), which lie above the level of the pectoralis minor tendon in continuity with the lateral nodes and which receive the efferents of all the other axillary groups and drains in to subclavian lymphatic trunk.

Interpectoral (Rotters node) - a few nodes lying between the pectoralis major and minor muscles.(Level II)

Internal mammary nodes drain posterior one-third of breast.

questions.text: A 9-year-old girl is brought to the casualty with a history of abdominal pain and vomiting for the past 4 hours. On examination, the patient is febrile. Rebound tenderness in the right iliac fossa is seen. Which among the following is the preferred imaging modality in this patient?

choices.text: Erect X Ray of the abdomen

questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of acute appendicitis. In the pediatric population, ultrasound of the abdomen is the preferred imaging modality to identify the presence of an inflamed appendix. It avoids the risk of radiation exposure. 

In adults, the best imaging modality is a CT scan.

questions.text: In which of the following conditions will you perform the Kasai procedure?
questions.solution:
Kasai procedure (Roux-en-Y hepatoportoenterostomy) is done for extrahepatic biliary atresia. In the Kasai procedure, the occluded extrahepatic bile ducts are excised and a jejunal Roux loop is anastomosed to the hepatic hilum.

Extrahepatic biliary atresia (EHBA) is defined as a partial or total absence of permeable bile duct between porta hepatis and the duodenum. It is due to inflammatory fibrosis of the biliary tree. It leads to obstruction to bile flow thereby causing leaking of conjugated bilirubin into the circulation.

Associated anomalies include cardiac lesions, polysplenia, situs inversus, absent vena cava, and a preduodenal portal vein.

HIDA scan is the investigation of choice for EHBA. Intraoperative cholangiogram is the gold standard for diagnosis.

Management of extrahepatic biliary atresia
Type I

Atresia restricted to the common bile duct

Roux-en-Y hepaticojejunostomy
Type II

Atresia of the common hepatic duct

 Kasai procedure (Roux-en-Y hepatoportoenterostomy)
Type III

Atresia of the right and left hepatic duct

Infants with biliary atresia, who do not achieve successful drainage after Kasai's procedure, require liver transplantation within the first year of life. It is the most common reason for liver transplantation in children.

questions.text: A 33-year-old female patient comes with complaints of menorrhagia for the past 3 months. The duration and regularity of her menstrual cycles are normal. Non-hormonal management has been tried without success. What is the most appropriate next step?
questions.solution:
Hormonal therapy is the next best step in the given scenario of menorrhagia that is unresponsive to non-hormonal therapy. 

Menorrhagia is defined as heavy but regular menstrual bleeding. It can be acute (<6 months) or chronic (>6 months).

It is managed as follows:

  • Medical - first line of treatment.  
    • NSAIDs
    • Tranexamic acid  
    • OCPs/progestogens - if non-hormonal management fails 
    • Mirena IUCD
    • Blood transfusion, if required 
  • Surgical - if medical management fails, depending on the diagnosis:
    • Endometrial ablation - hysteroscopic, TCRE, RITEA, microwave, NovaSure, etc
    • Uterine artery embolization
    • Uterine tamponade
    • Hysterectomy - if all minimally invasive methods fail

questions.text: In modern obstetrics, which of the following investigations is used for monitoring the fetus of an Rh-negative sensitized mother?
questions.solution:
MCA doppler peak systolic velocity (PSV) is used for the monitoring of fetuses in Rh-negative sensitized mothers.

MCA PSV is enhanced due to increased cardiac output and decreased viscosity of fetal blood. 

If the MCA PSV exceeds 1.5 MoM (multiples of the median) and the gestational age is less than 34 or 35 weeks, fetal blood sampling should be considered. MCA Doppler PSV has replaced amniocentesis as the preferred test for the detection of anemia.

questions.text: A 33-week-pregnant lady with pre-eclampsia presenting with features suggestive of HELLP syndrome should be best managed by _______

choices.text: Give steroids and wait till 37 weeks
Give MgSo4 and deliver at 36 weeks

questions.solution:
The definitive management of PIH/eclampsia is termination of pregnancy only.

Indications for termination of pregnancy, irrespective of gestational age, in cases of pre-eclampsia are as follows:

  • Severe pre-eclampsia
  • Eclampsia (give MgSO4 followed by induction of labor)
  • HELLP syndrome
  • Pulmonary edema
  • Significant renal dysfunction, coagulopathy
  • Fetal compromise

questions.text: Two girls in the same class are diagnosed with meningococcal meningitis. Their 12-year old friend from the same class  is afraid of contracting the disease.  What advice should be given to the exposed students?
questions.solution:
Antibiotic prophylaxis is provided to the close contacts of persons with confirmed meningococcal disease.

Treatment is provided to the contacts within 24 hours of identification of the index case. The antibiotics effective include rifampicin, ciprofloxacin, ceftriaxone, and azithromycin.

questions.text: A construction worker got entrapped in a collapsed building. He sustained severe injury over his legs. Which of the following features is unlikely to be seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a worker sustaining severe injury over his leg following entrapment is suggestive of crush syndrome. In this condition, hypokalemia is not seen.

Crush syndrome can result when a limb is compressed for a prolonged period. For e.g. getting crushed or entrapped in a vehicle or rubble and after extended use of a pneumatic antishock garment. This results in hypoperfusion and myonecrosis in the crushed limb. When the limb is released from the compression, toxic metabolites get released to cause reperfusion injury. 

Crush syndrome can result in a systemic reaction due to tissue necrosis. Free myoglobin can lead to acute tubular necrosis and renal failure. Myonecrosis can lead to metabolic acidosis with hyperkalemia and hypocalcemia. The procoagulants escaped into the systemic circulation can produce systemic coagulopathy. 

Management of crush syndrome:

  • Encouraging high urine flow, along with alkalization of urine with sodium bicarbonate to prevent precipitation of myoglobin in the renal tubules
  • Renal hemofiltration if there is oliguria or renal failure
  • If compartment syndrome is confirmed, then fasciotomy is performed
  • Radical excision of necrosed muscle to avoid sepsis
  • Aggressive management of the open wound

Related Pearl: Acute compartment and Crush syndrome

1. Acute Compartment Syndrome

Acute compartment syndrome is an elevation of the intracompartmental pressure (ICP) which increases the risk for tissue ischemia and necrosis.

Causes: Fractures (70%) and severe soft tissue injuries (30%). Common fractures causing compartment syndrome include tibial diaphyseal (most common), distal radius, and forearm fractures. 

Pathology: Increased pressure in one of the osseofascial compartments due to bleeding, oedema or inflammation. A vicious cycle of ischemia → edema→ ischemia leading to necrosis of the muscles and nerves within the compartment in 6 hours or less. 

Clinical features: Five Ps: Pain, Paraesthesia, Pallor, Paralysis and Pulselessness. 

Management: Fasciotomy to decompress the threatened compartment if the differential pressure (ΔP) goes < 30 mmHg. 

 

2. Crush syndrome 

Crush syndrome is the systemic manifestation of muscle necrosis. It is commonly caused due to prolonged external compression of an extremity. 

Causes: Crush injuries sustained during motor vehicle accidents, earthquakes, mining and other occupational accidents.

Pathology: Underperfusion of muscle causes myonecrosis. When the limb is freed, there is a release of toxic metabolites causing reperfusion injury. Reactive oxygen metabolites create further tissue injury. Free myoglobin can get precipitated in the renal glomeruli. 

Clinical features: The affected limb is pulseless, red, swollen and blistered. Sensation and muscle power may be lost. There can be signs of impaired renal function, metabolic acidosis, hyperkalemia and hypocalcaemia.

Management: Encouraging high urine output, alkalization of the urine, hemofiltration, radical excision of dead muscles, fasciotomy if there is compartment syndrome.

questions.text: A patient presented with pleuritic chest pain and absent breath sounds on the right side. A pleural effusion is suspected. What is the best chest x-ray view to diagnose this condition?
questions.solution:
Lateral decubitus view is the best view to identify pleural effusion. It can identify as little as 25 ml of pleural fluid.

Features of chest radiograph in pleural effusion:

  • Presence of free pleural fluid 
  • Blunting of costophrenic angle 
  • Ellis-S curve – This is a radiological illusion and occurs as a medial radiological density due to the presence of partially aerated lung between the anterior and posterior fluid layers, whereas laterally the density is higher due to the presence of fluid only. The actual fluid level is horizontal.

The image given below shows a lateral decubitus view showing pleural effusion.

Marking A shows fluid layering in the right pleural cavity. Marking B shows the normal width of the lung in the cavity. The amount of pleural fluid can be approximately quantified by measuring the distance A.

Best investigation for minimal pleural effusion is USG.

The minimal amount of fluid required to be detected on imaging for pleural effusion:

  • Lateral view – 75 ml pleural fluid
  • PA view – 200 ml pleural fluid
  • Lateral decubitus - <25 ml pleural fluid

The image below depicts pleural effusion in chest X-ray PA view.

questions.text: A 72-year-old woman is admitted with complaints of fever with dysuria for 5 days. Her husband reports that she now appears withdrawn and apathetic. She had complained of seeing bugs crawling on her hand. She is drowsy on examination. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of an acute decline in the level of awareness and visual hallucinations (seeing bugs crawling on hand) in an elderly female admitted with fever and dysuria suggests a diagnosis of delirium.

Delirium is characterized by:

  • Acute decline in the level of awareness 
  • Global impairment of cognitive functions (particularly attention)

It also involves:

  • Perceptual disturbances like illusions and hallucinations
  • Abnormal psychomotor activity
  • Sleep cycle impairment.

The Confusion Assessment Method (CAM) is a diagnostic algorithm for delirium. The diagnosis of delirium requires the presence of features 1 and 2 and either feature 3 or 4.

  • Feature 1: Acute onset and fluctuating course
    • Positive responses to the following questions satisfy this feature:
      Is there evidence of an acute change in mental status from the patient’s baseline? Does it fluctuate during the day, or does it increase and decrease in severity?
  • Feature 2: Inattention
    • Positive response to the following question satisfies this feature: Is there difficulty focusing attention, easily distractibility, or difficulty keeping track of what was being said?
  • Feature 3: Disorganized thinking
    • A positive response to the following question satisfies this feature: Was the patient’s thinking disorganized or incoherent. Was there rambling or irrelevant conversation, an unclear or illogical flow of ideas, or unpredictable switching from subject to subject?
  • Feature 4: Altered level of consciousness
    • This feature is satisfied by any answer other than “alert” to the following question: Rate the patient’s level of consciousness: alert (normal), vigilant (hyperalert), lethargic (drowsy, easily aroused), stupor (difficult to arouse), or coma (unarousable)?

The scale may not identify the full spectrum of patients with delirium, but all patients who are acutely confused should be presumed delirious. A course that fluctuates over hours or days and may worsen at night is known as sundowning. It is typically seen in delirium, but is not essential for the diagnosis.

Other screening tools that can aid in identifying patients with delirium are:

  • Nursing Delirium Screening Scale (NuDESC)
  • Organic Brain Syndrome Scale
  • Delirium Rating Scale
  • ICU version of the CAM
  • Delirium Detection Score

Related Pearl: Delirium vs Dementia

Delirium

Dementia

Hallmark is impaired consciousness

Loss of memory and intellectual abilities

More common in children and elderly 

More common in the elderly 

Associated physical findings:

  • Acute medical illness 
  • Autonomic dysfunction
  • Abnormal EEG 
  • Carphologia or floccillation (picking movements at cover-sheets and clothes) 

Associated physical findings:

  • No medical illness
  • Little autonomic dysfunction

  • Sundowning (symptoms much worse at night)

Course:

  • Develops quickly
  • Fluctuating course with lucid intervals (waxing and waning)

questions.text: Which of the following inhaled anesthetics is the induction agent of choice in a patient planned for surgery under GA?
questions.solution:
Sevoflurane is the induction agent of choice among inhalational anesthetics. 

It is non-pungent and has low blood-gas solubility (0.65), allowing for smooth induction of anesthesia.

Option A: Halothane has high blood gas solubility, leading to a slower induction of anesthesia.

Option C: Desflurane and isoflurane are airway irritants, of which desflurane is the most pungent inhalational agent. Hence, they are not used for the induction of anesthesia as they can precipitate laryngospasm. These agents are used only during the maintenance of anesthesia.

Option D: N2O has a MAC value of 104%, which makes it the least potent inhaled anesthetic. It is always used in combination with more potent volatile agents.

questions.text: In which of the following cases would you prescribe systemic corticosteroids?
questions.solution:
Impetigo herpetiformis (pustular psoriasis of pregnancy) is the only definitive indication for systemic steroids.

Steroids can also be used for the control of acute symptoms like ARDS accompanying pustular psoriasis.

Steroids are contraindicated in all other forms of psoriasis as sudden withdrawal can trigger severe pustular or erythrodermic psoriasis. As most of the other medications are contraindicated in pregnancy, this is the only definitive indication for systemic steroids.

questions.text: Patients with which of the following tumors are best treated with radiotherapy?
questions.solution:
Patients diagnosed with seminoma are best treated with radiotherapy, as it is a highly radiosensitive tumor. 

Related Pearl: Radiosensitive and Radioresistant Tumors

Highly radiosensitive tumors are

  • Lymphoma
  • Seminoma
  • Myeloma
  • Ewing’s sarcoma
  • Wilm’s tumour

 Highly radioresistant tumors are

  • Melanoma
  • Osteosarcoma
  • Pancreatic carcinoma
  • Hepatic carcinoma
  • Renal cell carcinoma
